qas.question: Who presided over classes at a scholae monasticae?
In the chronology of academic institutions, where are Christian cathedral schools compared to universities?
What church is said to be responsible for the formation of universities?
During which era did universities grow out of already extant schools?

plausible_answers.text: Christian cathedral schools or monastic schools

qas.question: Where did education originally take place across the world?

plausible_answers.text: Christian cathedral schools or monastic schools

qas.question: What type of schools forbid women to teach?
What church encouraged but did not get directly involved in forming universities?
What caused most existing schools to decline?
During which era did universities grow out of monasteries?

plausible_answers.text: the aegis of the Latin Church by papal bull

qas.question: What were the earliest monasteries developed under?

plausible_answers.text: University of Naples Federico II, Charles University in Prague, Jagiellonian University in Kraków

qas.question: What are three monasteries started by Kings?
Where were most new universities funded from?

context: European higher education took place for hundreds of years in <b5_0><b6_0>Christian cathedral schools or <a0_0>monastic schools<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> (scholae monasticae), in which <a1_0><b10_0>monks and nuns<b10_0/><a1_0/> taught classes; evidence of these <a2_0>immediate <b7_0>forerunners<a2_0/> of the later university<b7_0/> at many places dates back to the 6th century. The earliest <b9_0>universities<b9_0/> were developed under <b12_0>the aegis of the <a3_0><b8_0>Latin Church<b8_0/><a3_0/> by papal bull<b12_0/> as studia generalia and perhaps from cathedral schools. It is possible, however, that the development of cathedral schools into universities was quite rare, with the University of Paris being an exception. Later they were also founded by Kings (<b13_0>University of Naples Federico II, Charles University in Prague, Jagiellonian University in Kraków<b13_0/>) or municipal administrations (University of Cologne, University of Erfurt). In the <a4_0><b11_0>early medieval period<b11_0/><a4_0/>, most new universities were founded from <b14_0>pre-existing schools<b14_0/>, usually when these schools were deemed to have become primarily sites of higher education. Many historians state that universities and cathedral schools were a continuation of the interest in learning promoted by monasteries.
